titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the UNITE HERE Records LSC.2325
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Margarite Rank under the supervision of Julie Graham, June 12, 2017.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2021 March 3.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

publicationstmt.p: This record is made available under an Universal 1.0 Public Domain Dedication Creative Commons license.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-01-10 13:54:43 -0800.

physdesc.extent: (25 boxes, 15 cartons, 11 flat boxes, 3 oversize flat boxes, 1 flat file)

did.abstract: UNITE-HERE Local 11 traces its origins to the Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders International union founded in 1891 and has been active in Southern California since the 1930s. Local 11 partnered with other labor and community organizations to play a key role in reviving the Los Angeles labor movement during the 1990s and 2000s. Local 11 grew through mergers with HERE locals in Santa Monica (Local 814) in 2002 and Orange County/Long Beach (Local 681) in 2008. HERE International merged with UNITE (Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees) to form UNITE-HERE in July, 2004. This collection consists of materials documenting UNITE-HERE Locals 11, 814 and 681 and includes files of union leaders Maria Elena Durazo, Kurt Petersen and Tom Walsh, Executive Board meeting minutes, newspaper coverage in English and Spanish of union campaigns, union serial publications, booklets and videos, television coverage of organizing campaigns, transcribed oral histories, photographs and ephemera.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English, some materials in Spanish.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Box 52 containing quilt top banner requires special handling for access. Please contact Special Collections reference (spec-coll@library.ucla.edu) for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS DIGITAL AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains both processed and unprocessed digital and audiovisual materials. Digital and audiovisual materials are not currently available for access, unless otherwise noted in a Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note at the series and file levels. All requests to access processed digital and audiovisual materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], UNITE HERE records (Collection 2325). Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Pre-processing by Gina Risetter in the Institute for Research on Labor and Employment, 2016. Additional processing completed by Margaret Rank supervised by Julie Graham, 2017. Finding aid scope and content note and organizational history note authored by Vivian Rothstein and Danielle Wilson.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: UNITE-HERE Local 11 traces its origins to the Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders International Union founded in 1891 and has been active in Southern California since the 1930s. Along with Justice for janitors, LAANE and the County Federation of Labor, it played a key role in reviving the Los Angeles labor movement during the 1990s and 2000s. HERE International merged with UNITE (Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees Union) to form UNITE-HERE in July, 2004.

Local 11 has been involved with high profile organizing activities throughout Los Angeles. In the 1990s they led a multi-year campaign to unionize the New Otani Hotel in Little Tokyo through a card check process as well as campaigns to unionize workers at the Ambassador Hotel and luxury hotels on Santa Monica's beach front. In 2004 they participated in a national campaign with major hotels across the United States and won important concessions from local hotels. The local has been a strong proponent of Living Wage and Minimum Wage Ordinances in L.A., Santa Monica and Long Beach and helped create the Los Angeles Alliance for a New Economy (LAANE).

Historically waiters, bartenders, waitresses, kitchen and cleaning staff organized into separate locals or chapters. By the 1970s, most locals were geographically based, and included both front of the house staff (e.g., waiters and bartenders) and back of the house staff (e.g. kitchen, cleaning, etc.). During the 1980s and 1990s, the Los Angeles and Santa Monica HERE locals experienced leadership strains, with long serving leaders failing to respond to an increasingly immigrant workforce and anti-union climate;

Maria Elena Durazo, emerged as a reform leader of Local 11 in the late 1980s, leading several successful organizing drives for HERE, and championing the cause of back of the house staff, mainly Latin American immigrant women. In 1989, Durazo was elected Local 11 president, becoming one of the first Latina leaders of a major American union local. She would eventually serve as Secretary Treasurer of the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor (2005 to 2014). In 1995, Local 814 in Santa Monica was placed in trusteeship and in an election the following year, organizer Tom Walsh became president. Kurt Petersen, who joined the United Farm Workers of Washington State as an organizer, started his association with HERE in 1995 and has served the Local and national organization in various capacities.

The geographic scope of Local 11 grew through mergers with local unions in Santa Monica (Local 814) in 2002, and Orange County/Long Beach (Local 681) in 2008. Tom Walsh became the president of Local 11 after the mergers. The organization, with a membership of over 20,000 in 2018, embraces workers throughout Southern California, with a diverse membership from many immigrant communities as well as African-Americans, Latinos, and Asian-Americans. Industries represented include hotels, casinos, foodservice and retail airport concessions, stadiums and restaurants. Through grassroots mobilization of workers and community allies, Local 11 has improved working conditions, wages, and benefits for their members, transforming traditionally low-wage jobs to middle class jobs, and successfully participates in labor-management partnerships with employers to resolve issues in the workplace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of materials related to the UNITE HERE Local 11 labor union. Included are files documenting UNITE HERE Local 11, Local 814, and Local 681. The Local 11 records represent files of union leaders Maria Elena Durazo, Kurt Petersen, and Tom Walsh; Executive Board meeting minutes, and newspaper and television coverage of union events and working conditions. Local 814 records include files from Kurt Petersen, Tom Walsh, Bill Granfield, and Victor Valenzuela. The Local 681 records are largely union serial publications going back to the 1940s, The Mixer and Server and Catering Industry Employee, union booklets documenting wage scale and working condition agreements, union Bylaws and photographs. Union leader files document organizing efforts on behalf of the employees of Southern California hotels and restaurants including Miramar Sheraton and Loews in Santa Monica, among others; legal matters, many involving the NLRB; newspaper clippings, union flyers, videos and publications, and anti-union employer documents, shop steward training materials, photographs, oral history interviews, and ephemera. Events represented include the Immigrant Worker Freedom Ride (IWFR), the Los Angeles Alliance for a New Economy (LAANE) Santa Monica Living Wage campaign, LAX airport organizing campaigns, and Century Boulevard hotel organizing, among others.

controlaccess.subject: Labor unions -- California -- Los Angeles -- Archives.

did.langmaterial: Materials in this series are primarily in English, some materials in Spanish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of materials related to the work of UNITE HERE Local 11. Included are files from union leaders Maria Elena Durazo, Kurt Petersen, and Tom Walsh; Executive Board meeting minutes, chronological newsclippings in English and Spanish compiled by a union member identified as Carlitos, photographs, and ephemera. Union leader files may include newspaper clippings, union flyers and publications, a small amount of court case documentation, anti-union literature published by employers, shop steward training materials, and photographs. Materials represent events such as the International immigrant Workers Freedom Ride (IWFR) and LAANE's Century Boulevard hotels organizing campaign, among others; efforts on behalf of employees from Southern California hotels such as Hilton, Hyatt, Delfina, New Otani, and Sheraton, among others; and legal matters involving the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB). Also included are a small amount of buttons, posters, T-shirts, and a quilt top banner, created by hotel workers. Audiovisual materials include Immigrant Workers Freedom Ride videos, and Local 11 produced videos.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The series is arranged into the following subseries:
Subseries 1.1 Executive Board Meeting Minutes (1952-1954, 1961-1963, 1972-1982, 1994, undated)
Subseries 1.2 Kurt Petersen files (circa 1980s-2012)
Subseries 1.3 Tom Walsh files (circa 1970s-circa 2004)
Subseries 1.4 Maria Elena Durazo files (1989-2008)
Subseries 1.5 News clippings (1994-2013)
Subseries 1.6 Photographs and ephemera (1970s, 1991-2004, 1999, circa 2008)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The meeting minutes document the work of the Local 11 Executive Board during the early 1950s and 1960s, 1972-1982, and 1994. Additionally included is a Grievance Processing and Settlement / Arbitration Preparation and Presentation multi-page document.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Minutes are arranged in loose chronological order.

did.unittitle: Grievance Processing and Settlement/Arbitration Preparation and Presentation documentation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Kurt Petersen files document Local 11 efforts on behalf of employees employed at Southern California hotels and restaurants. Includes documentation concerning hotels such as Hilton and Hyatt, among others, a small number of files related to the Los Angeles Alliance for a New Economy (LAANE) Century Boulevard living wage campaign, anti union material, ephemera, articles pertaining to union and labor activities, and a small amount of union-related agreements.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by file titles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The bulk of Maria Elena Durazo files document the International Workers Freedom Ride (IWFR) in 2004. Includes ephemera, photographs, and a small number of planning materials, press clippings, and video recordings. Additionally, there is a small amount of materials related to Durazo's campaign run for Local 11 president.

arrangement.p: The files are arranged alphabetically by file title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the news clippings focus on Local 11 activities on behalf of employees employed in Southern California hotels and restaurants. Clippings are mostly from the La Opinión and Hoy , and to a lesser degree from the Los Angeles Times, The Los Angeles Business Journal, and Rafu Shimpo, among others. Much of the clippings were compiled by a union member identified as Carlitos.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Clippings are arranged in a loose chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of materials related to the work of Unite Here Local 814. Included are files from UNITE HERE leaders Bill Granfield, Kurt Petersen, Victor Valenzuela, and Tom Walsh, photographs, and ephemera. Files document union supported events such as the Tourism Industry Development Council's (TIDC, later known as LAANE) Santa Monica Living Wage and LAX hotel organizing campaigns; efforts on behalf of employees from Southern California hotels such as Miramar Sheraton, Loews, Airport Marina, Viscount, Holiday Inn LAX, and the Manhattan Beach Radisson, among others; and legal matters involving the NLRB. The files may include magazine and newspaper clippings, a small amount of court case documentation, anti-union literature published by employers, shop steward training materials, union flyers and publications, photographs, and ephemera. Some materials, particularly the clippings, are in Spanish.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Series is arranged into the following subseries:
Subseries 2.1 Kurt Petersen files (circa 1980s-2004)
Subseries 2.2 Tom Walsh files (circa 1980s-circa 1990s, 2001)
Subseries 2.3 Bill Granfield files (1988-1997, 1999)
Subseries 2.4 Victor Valenzuela files (circa 1950s-1993)
Subseries 2.5 Gary Guthman files (1988-1990)
Subseries 2.6 Photographs and ephemera (1996-2002)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the series comprises periodical publications and union booklets related to the work of Local 681. Periodical publications include Serving America, The Mixer and Server, and Catering Industry Employee, (The Mixer and Server continued publication under title of Catering Industry Employee starting in October 1929), among others. Union booklets document employee wage scale and working conditions, benefits, and constitutions and by-laws. Additionally there are two photographs albums, clippings, and ephemera.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is in original order.

Union booklets mostly regarding wage scale and working conditions
Union booklets mostly regarding constitutions and by-laws
Union booklets mostly regarding wage scale and working conditions for specific businesses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appear to be identified with specific Long Beach and/or Orange County business names. Some locations annotated and/or printed on booklets, such as Anaheim Bowl; Arnold's Farm House; Aztec Bowl; Buttery; Century Bowl; Chris & Pitts BBQ; Dal Rae; Del Rio Lanes; Dimitres Restaurant; El Adobe; Francois; Glider Inn; Heck's; Highland Bowl; Hillview Bowl; Huntington Lanes; International City Club; Keona; Long Beach Harbor Inn; Loyd's; Marina Lanes; Mike's Restaurant; New Method School of Bartending; Phillip's Chicken Pie; Pioneer Bowl; Plaza Lanes; Premier Lanes; Rossmore Bowl; Sierra; Stem Room; Sut's; Tee Cee's; Two J's Café; and Village Inn.

did.unittitle: Union booklets mostly regarding wage scale and working conditions for specific businesses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appear to be identified with specific Long Beach and/or Orange County business names. Some locations annotated and.or printed on booklets, such as Alfred's; Anaheim Hilton and Towers; Anaheim Stadium and Anaheim Convention Center; Boyle's; Captain's Quarters; Concession Air, Inc.; Daly's Cocktails; Disneyland; Evan's Family Restaurant; Hilton At The Park; Hof's Hut; Hubert's Cafeteria; Huntington Hotel; It'l Do; Johnnie W. Miller Sandwich Company; Kettle, Little's; Los Alamitos Race Course; Lucy's; Mannings; Nationwide Food Services; Orbit Coffee Shop; Phil's Brite Spot; The Phone Booth; Poor Richard's; Press Club; Revere House; Ric A Box; Royal Inn Hotel of Anaheim; Flagship International (Sky Chefs); Steak 'n' Stuff Restaurant; and The Trap.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: From the Los Angeles Times and Orange County Register, among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: St. Jude Hospital citation; Culinary Alliance membership to Convention and Visitor's Bureau of Long Beach both presented to Local 681; and AFL conference attendance certificates for Kathryn Arnold and Jack Arnold.

did.unittitle: City of Hope Medical Center recognition to Culinary Local 681 - plaque
